Subject: Replace genotypic distance and speciation mechanisms in hyperNEAT by
 a novelty distance comparison on the outputs of the CPPN
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=422167445; y=GO2iarsRWmyYxchfpSSzqE1vwC_D53kuRIqiB6bbGouh7Ds

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Hello,

I am currently experimenting with hyperNEAT and was just wondering if
anybody tried to replace the NEAT mechanisms found in hyperNEAT (speciation,
distance based on innovation numbers and weights in the cppn) by a distance
between the behaviors of the CPPN.  This may not be clear, so I will
developp:

The NEAT part in hyperNEAT improves the evolution of CPPNs, and, if you
remove both the speciation protection mechanism and the distance between
genotypes based on the innovation numbers, the "HyperNeuralNetwork" has bad
fitnesses on the different benchmarks (the fitness landscape of the cppn
seems to be quite deceptive).

However, considering the recent results on diversity and novelty objectives,
has anybody tried to replace them (innovation numbers and speciation
mechanisms) with an explicit objective which would take into account the
novelty of behavior of the CPPN ?

This is straightforward to implement for a given substrate: for each query
of the cppn of an individual (each time you compute a weight between two
substrate nodes), append the obtained weight to a vector. It is then
possible to define a novelty objective based on a conventional distance
metric between these "CPPN Behavior" vectors.

An additionnal benefit I see from this approach, and if I understood neat
innovation numbers correctly, is that the mathematical functions used for
each node in the cppn are not taken into account by the neat metric (if two
nodes with a same innovation number have mutated to present different
mathematical functions, this does not increase the NEAT distance between
them).

I have already have preliminary results showing that this metric is an
improvement over my partial implementation of hyperNEAT, however, I only
used a distance based on the innovation numbers and not the species
protection mechanism.

Paul

--000e0cdf9d066be0ad04a5e43b1d
Content-Type: text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
